00068 /**
00069  * \ingroup Library
00070  * \brief  Error notification log counts
00071  *
00072  * \description
00073  *
00074  *    This is a simple global data structure for counting the number
00075  *    of warning, error, and log messages that have been posted.
00076  */
00077 typedef struct {
00078   unsigned int errors;
00079   unsigned int warnings;
00080   unsigned int logs;
00081   unsigned int debugs;
00082 } FC_LogCount;
00083 
00084 extern FC_LogCount _fc_log_count;
00085 
00086 
00087 /** 
00088  * \name Message functions
00089  *
00090  * Use these to generate various levels of messages. The messages
00091  * that are actually sent depend on the verbosity level of the library.
00092  */
00093 //-------------------------------
00094 //@{
00095  
00096 /** 
00097  * \ingroup Library
00098  * \brief Print an error message to stderr.
00099  *
00100  * \description
00101  *
00102  *    If the library verbosity indicates that error messages should
00103  *    be printed, this Macro prints the message to stderr.
00104  *    The message can consist of a format string and arguments,
00105  *    just like printf (but you don't need the trailing '\\n').
00106  *    The output will be 
00107  *
00108  *    'Error:function_name[filename:line#]: message'.
00109  *
00110  * \note
00111  *    This is a 'variadic macro' (i.e. it can have variable number of
00112  *    of arguments. I'm not sure how well supported it is
00113  *    over different compilers. __VA_ARGS__ is a predefined macro
00114  *    that maps the '...' in the argument list. The '##'
00115  *    is supposed to delete the preceding ',' if __VA_ARGS__ is empty.
00116  * 
00117  * \modifications 
00118  *    - 05/19/04  WSK, Created
00119  */
00120 #define fc_printfErrorMessage(message, ...)  \
00121   { \
00122     _fc_log_count.errors++; \
00123     if (fc_getLibraryVerbosity() >= FC_ERROR_MESSAGES)  { \
00124       fprintf(stderr, "FC Error:%s[%s:%d]: " message "\n", \
00125               __func__, __FILE__, __LINE__, ##__VA_ARGS__); \
00126       fflush(NULL); \
00127     } \
00128   }
00129 
00130 /** 
00131  * \ingroup Library
00132  * \brief Print a warning message to stdout.
00133  *
00134  * \description
00135  *
00136  *    If the library verbosity indicates that warning messages should
00137  *    be printed, this Macro prints the message to stderr.
00138  *    The message can consist of a format string and arguments,
00139  *    just like printf (but you don't need the trailing '\\n').
00140  *    The output will be 
00141  *
00142  *    'FC Warning:function_name[filename:line#]: message'.
00143  *
00144  * \note
00145  *    This is a 'variadic macro' (i.e. it can have variable number of
00146  *    of arguments. I'm not sure how well supported it is
00147  *    over different compilers. __VA_ARGS__ is a predefined macro
00148  *    that maps the '...' in the argument list. The '##'
00149  *    is supposed to delete the preceding ',' if __VA_ARGS__ is empty.
00150  * 
00151  * \modifications 
00152  *    - 05/19/04  WSK, Created
00153  */
00154 #define fc_printfWarningMessage(message, ...)  \
00155   { \
00156     _fc_log_count.warnings++; \
00157     if (fc_getLibraryVerbosity() >= FC_WARNING_MESSAGES) { \
00158       fprintf(stderr, "FC Warning:%s[%s:%d]: " message "\n", \
00159               __func__, __FILE__, __LINE__, ##__VA_ARGS__); \
00160       fflush(NULL); \
00161     } \
00162   }
00163 
00164 /** 
00165  * \ingroup Library
00166  * \brief Print a log message to stdout.
00167  *
00168  * \description
00169  *
00170  *    If the library verbosity indicates that log messages should
00171  *    be printed, this Macro prints the message to stdout.
00172  *    The message can consist of a format string and arguments,
00173  *    just like printf (but you don't need the trailing '\\n').
00174  *    The output will be 
00175  *
00176  *    'FC Log:function_name[filename:line#]: message'.
00177  *
00178  * \note
00179  *    This is a 'variadic macro' (i.e. it can have variable number of
00180  *    of arguments. I'm not sure how well supported it is
00181  *    over different compilers. __VA_ARGS__ is a predefined macro
00182  *    that maps the '...' in the argument list. The '##'
00183  *    is supposed to delete the preceding ',' if __VA_ARGS__ is empty.
00184  * 
00185  * \modifications 
00186  *    - 05/19/04  WSK, Created
00187  */
00188 #define fc_printfLogMessage(message, ...)  \
00189   { \
00190     _fc_log_count.logs++; \
00191     if (fc_getLibraryVerbosity() >= FC_LOG_MESSAGES) { \
00192       fprintf(stdout, "FC Log:%s[%s:%d]: " message "\n", \
00193               __func__, __FILE__, __LINE__, ##__VA_ARGS__); \
00194       fflush(NULL); \
00195     } \
00196   }
00197 
00198 /** 
00199  * \ingroup Library
00200  * \brief Print a debug message to stdout.
00201  *
00202  * \description
00203  *
00204  *    If the library verbosity indicates that debug messages should
00205  *    be printed, this Macro prints the message to stdout.
00206  *    The message can consist of a format string and arguments,
00207  *    just like printf (but you don't need the trailing '\\n').
00208  *    The output will be 
00209  *
00210  *    'FC Debug:function_name[filename:line#]: message'.
00211  *
00212  * \note
00213  *    This is a 'variadic macro' (i.e. it can have variable number of
00214  *    of arguments. I'm not sure how well supported it is
00215  *    over different compilers. __VA_ARGS__ is a predefined macro
00216  *    that maps the '...' in the argument list. The '##'
00217  *    is supposed to delete the preceding ',' if __VA_ARGS__ is empty.
00218  * 
00219  * \modifications 
00220  *    - 05/19/04  WSK, Created
00221  */
00222 #define fc_printfDebugMessage(message, ...)  \
00223   { \
00224     _fc_log_count.debugs++; \
00225     if (fc_getLibraryVerbosity() >= FC_DEBUG_MESSAGES) { \
00226       fprintf(stdout, "FC Debug:%s[%s:%d]: " message "\n", \
00227               __func__, __FILE__, __LINE__, ##__VA_ARGS__); \
00228       fflush(NULL); \
00229     } \
00230   }
